summary:
Dr. Vykuntaraju K.N. currently working as Prof and Head of the department of pediatric neurology at Indira Gandhi Institute of Child Health, Bangalore. He did DM in Pediatric Neurology from the prestigious All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), New Delhi in June 2010. 
He has more than 500 publications in various national and international journals and abstracts in conferences (100 pub-med indexed, 100 others indexed, 300 abstracts). He has got more than 30 awards for various papers in conferences at state, national and international conferences. He is an author and editor of books cerebral palsy and early stimulation and cerebral palsy manual. He is an author of more than 25 chapters in other textbooks. He is a guest speaker in more than 200 state and national conferences. 
He is a teacher for postgraduate students in Pediatrics, fellow students of pediatrics in various pediatric subspecialties. He is a postgraduate guide for more than 25 students and guided them in completing their thesis. He is a teacher for MD pediatrics and DM neurology residents from other medical colleges across Karnataka. He is a guide for PhD and DM students.
He is investigator for more than 10 projects under ICMR, DBT, and University of Liverpool, UK: National Institute for Health Research, UK. He has organized various state and national conferences, workshops, and CME programs in pediatric neurology. 
He is a member of various organizations like the Indian academy of pediatrics (IAP), associations of child neurology-India (AOCN-India), and others. He is serving as an editorial member of several reputed journals. He is a reviewer for journals like Indian Pediatrics, Indian Journal of Pediatrics, Journal of Child Neurology, and many more.
The pediatric neurology fellowship course under Rajiv Gandhi University of Health Sciences (RGUHS) in the institute is the first of its kind in the state of Karnataka to have started and it has gradually grown into a very competitive and highly sought out a training program in the country as different clinical fellows from various parts of the country have come here for training and have completed their fellowship.

publications.description:
Immunological involvement of peripheral nervous system in non-
Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is very rare and it may be difficult to
differentiate it from vincristine-induced neuropathy. We report clinical
and electrophysiological findings of an 8-year-old male with NHL
who developed acute onset fulminant motor sensory autonomic neuropathy
during induction chemotherapy which included vincristine.
Characteristic clinical picture and nerve conduction studies favored
Guillain–Barr´e syndrome. The patient improved rapidly with intravenous
immunoglobulin and supportive care. It is possible that an
immune mechanism damaged the peripheral nervous system in the
patient without ruling out the adverse effects of vinca alkaloids.
publications.name: Acute Onset Flaccid Quadriparesis in Pediatric Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: Vincristine Induced or Guillain–Barr´e Syndrome?

publications.description:
Appropriate management of raised intracranial
pressure begins with stabilization of the patient and
simultaneous assessment of the level of sensorium and the
cause of raised intracranial pressure. Stabilization is
initiated with securing the airway, ventilation and circulatory
function. The identification of surgically remediable
conditions is a priority. Emergent use of external ventricular
drain or ventriculo-peritoneal shunt may be lifesaving in
selected patients. In children with severe coma, signs of
herniation or acutely elevated intracranial pressure, treatment
should be started prior to imaging or invasive
monitoring. Emergent use of hyperventilation and mannitol
are life saving in such situations. Medical management
involves careful use of head elevation, osmotic agents, and
avoiding hypotonic fluids. Appropriate care also includes
avoidance of aggravating factors. For refractory intracranial
hypertension, barbiturate coma, hypothermia, or decompressive
craniectomy should be considered.
publications.name: Management of Raised Intracranial Pressure
West syndrome secondary to Aicardi syndrome with Type 2b Inter-hemispheric Cyst
publications.description:
Introduction
Aicardi syndrome, an unusual condition, presents with the classic triad of agenesis of the corpus callosum (ACC), infantile spasms, and chorioretinal lacunae.  It is known to occur exclusively in females due to its X-linked transmission. Very few case reports of Aicardi syndrome with an interhemispheric cyst have been published from India. 
Case report
 A 6 month old female infant presented with complaints of asymmetrical spasms, more on the left side since 3 months of age. The child had global developmental delay. On examination she had Microcephaly with increased tone and reflexes. Ophthalmological examination revealed right sided optic nerve head coloboma.
MRI of the brain showed ACC. A multiloculated inter hemispheric cyst seen on both sides of the midline. EEG shows asymmetrical hypsarrythmias. Earlier child received phenobarbitone, Valproate, levetiracetam without any significant improvement. The child was started on Vigabatrin after which the infantile spasms subsided. 
Discussion
In our case, all the clinical and radiographic criteria for Aicardi and west syndrome were fulfilled. In addition, the patient had an interhemispheric cyst- Type 2b. This report thus demonstrates the importance of keeping a high index of suspicion for other CNS malformations when ACC is present. An MRI may thus be helpful to determine a more precise prognosis.
Conclusions 
Aicardi syndrome should be suspected in any girl child presenting with infantile spasms, visual problems & Neuroimaging showing agenesis of corpus callosum and should look for other malformations of brain.

A 7-year-old boy with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, receiving antiretroviral drugs
for 2 years, presented with a recent onset of myoclonic jerks and cognitive deterioration. On
examination, he manifested myoclonic jerks once every 10-15 seconds. His electroencephalogram
indicated periodic complexes, and his cerebrospinal fluid tested positive for measles
antibodies.
publications.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency syndrome with Subacute Sclerosing panencephalitis AIDS with SSPE

publications.description:
Summary
Purpose: Autonomic symptoms frequently occur during seizures. There are reports that the
adult group of intractable epilepsy patients have different autonomic profile than the well
controlled epilepsy, but there is no clear evidence in the children epilepsy group, therefore,
we planned to study the autonomic profile in well controlled and refractory epilepsy children
by recording the short-term heart rate variability (HRV).
Methods: This cross sectional study was conducted in a tertiary care hospital between July
2008 and June 2009. Children with mean age of 9.1
±
3.3 years were enrolled. Three groups
of children, 40 in each group namely, refractory epilepsy, well controlled epilepsy and normal
control children were included. Children who had chronic systemic diseases and were on drugs
that cause autonomic dysfunction were excluded. All children underwent short term heart rate
variability testing. Data was analyzed in time domain and frequency domain.
Results: pNN50 was significantly lower in children with refractory epilepsy than the well control
as well as healthy controls. Rest of the parameters of time domain and frequency domain were
comparable between the groups.
Conclusions: Our study showed that parasympathetic activity is lower in refractory epilepsy
children. However, autonomic tone is comparable in well control versus healthy controls.
publications.name: Comparison of heart rate variability among children with well controlled versus refractory epilepsy: a cross-sectional study

publications.description:
We describe a 14-month-old girl who presented with arterial ischemic stroke due to moyamoya disease, unilateral renal agenesis
and external iliac artery stenosis. The association of moyamoya disease with renal agenesis and external iliac artery stenosis has not
been described before. This report expands the spectrum of moyamoya disease and suggests that moyamoya disease may have an
intrauterine onset.
publications.name: Renal agenesis and external iliac artery stenosis in an infant with moyamoya disease

publications.description:
We read with interest the case report on Thiamineresponsive
megaloblastic anemia (TRMA) [1]. We report
our experience with three children with TRMA in two
south Indian families.
publications.name: Thiamine Responsive Megaloblastic Anemia in Three Indian Children

publications.description:
A 5-year-old boy who presented with progressive ataxia, neuroregression, and worsening with febrile illnesses is described.
He also had myoclonic jerks and ptosis. His elder sister had died of a similar illness. Serial magnetic resonance imaging of the brain
demonstrated extensive abnormality of the cerebral white matter with rarefaction and cystic degeneration, suggestive of vanishing
white matter disease. The patient was found to be compound heterozygous for 2 new mutations in the gene EIF2B5, confirming
the diagnosis.
publications.name: Vanishing White Matter Disease Associated With Ptosis and Myoclonic Seizures

publications.description: Alternating hemiplegia of childhood is characterized by episodes of hemiplegia, various non-epileptic paroxysmal events and developmental delay. We are reporting a child with history of recurrent episodes of weakness involving either side of the body with developmental delay.  During the course of acute gastroenteritis in the hospital, child developed one sided weakness and completely recovered.
publications.name: Alternating hemiplegia of childhood during acute episode of gastroenteritis
Andersen Tawil Syndrome presenting with coma
publications.description: Andersen Tawil Syndrome (ATS) is a unique condition characterised by periodic paralysis, distinctive craniofacial and skeletal anomalies, and prolonged QT interval with a propensity toward malignant ventricular dysrhythmias. It is an autosomal dominant condition related to inward-rectifying potassium channel known as Kir2.1. Treatment includes carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and propronolol. We report a case presenting with sudden cardiovascular collapse followed by coma and acute flaccid paralysis

publications.name: Incidental detection of large unusual bilateral Arachnoid cyst
publications.description:
Introduction:
Arachnoid Cysts are congenital collections of CSF contained within the arachnoidal membrane and subarachnoid space of the cisterns and major cerebral fissures. Although some cysts remain stable, others can expand and compress surrounding structures, prompting evaluation. Most of these lesions become symptomatic in early childhood; hence, 60 to 90% of all patients with arachnoid cysts are children.
Case Presentation:
Five year old boy presented with fall while he was playing followed by four episodes of vomiting. No history of headache, convulsion, and altered sensorium. On examination, head circumference was 51 cms, with bilateral low set ears. CT scan of brain was taken; it showed bilateral symmetrical tense hypodense collections in the temporo sylvian extra-axial spaces, suggestive of arachnoid cyst. Possibility of glutaric acidemia was thought of. MRI brain showed large arachnoid cysts (5.5x4.4 cms) in sylvian regions bilaterally. They were seen to indent underlying cerebral parenchyma. His ABG, serum ammonia, lactate and TMS were normal. 
Discussion:
Arachnoid cysts may present in many different ways. Detection may occur during investigation for developmental delay, raised ICT, or incidentally following trauma. An association of Arachnoid cysts with Glutaric aciduria has been reported. Supratentorial cysts are frequently encountered; with nearly half of all cysts occurring within the sylvian fissure .Overall, arachnoid cysts account for approximately 1% of all intracranial mass lesions.
Conclusions
Incidental detection of large arachnoid cysts are common, and other causes should be considered before concluding these are the cause for CNS manifestations.

publications.name: Atypical Complication of Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever -Hydrocephalus
publications.description:
Introduction
Dengue infection is known to have varied clinical presentations. The incidence of neurological manifestation varies from 0.5% to 6.2%. We present a case of dengue with hydrocephalus.

Case
A 12 years old male presented with 5 days fever and two episodes of seizures. On examination, BP was 90/60 mm hg. Flushing of palms and soles with petechiae was present. GCS was 12/15. Investigations showed increased hematocrit, thrombocytopenia, elevated SGOT and SGPT. CT at admission showed hypodensity in bilateral thalamus and cerebellum. Dengue rapid test was positive. MRI showed signal changes in bilateral thalami and cerebellum. The child started deteriorating with decerebrate posturing, so CT  was done which showed significant dilatation of third and lateral ventricles due to increase in mass effect in posterior fossa. Subsequently external ventricular drainage tube was placed to drain the CSF. CSF Xcyton was strongly positive for dengue virus. Subsequently patient showed clinical improvement. Then EVD was removed after 3 days and repeat CT showed reduced size of ventricles. Patient was discharged without any neurological deficits. 
DISCUSSION
We present a proven case of dengue encephalitis with increased ICP due to hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus probably due to edema in cerebellum causing obstruction to CSF flow. The patient showed clinical improvement only after CSF drainage. CSF was positive for dengue antigen suggesting possible direct invasion of the virus in our case. 
CONCLUSION
In dengue fever neurological deterioration can be due to hydrocephalus, treatment of which can be life saving.

Introduction
Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS) is characterized by the onset of ophthalmoparesis and pigmentary retinopathy before age 20 years. We report a case of KSS initially presenting as Epilepsia Partialis Continua.
Case Report
A 10 year old male child presented with fever and convulsions. Seizures were of right complex partial seizures lasting for duration of 3 hours, followed by post-ictal drowsiness of 4 hours and sensory aphasia on regaining consciousness. From day 5, the child had persistent right focal convulsions, around 4 episodes per day, lasting for 5 to 10 minutes. On examination, bilateral Ptosis was present associated with right sided hemiparesis. Ophthalmological evaluation revealed pigmentary degeneration in peripheral retina. 
CPK levels were 964, and serum ammonia levels of 41. Lactate levels were elevated with a value of 78 mg/dl. MRI of the brain showed bilateral symmetric sub acute edema in the external capsules. CSF protein was increased 110mg/dl. Other investigations such as ECHO, ECG, and Arterial blood gas analysis were normal. He was treated with multiple anti epileptic drugs such as Valproate sodium, Clobazam. Levetiracetam and phenytoin, following which convulsions were controlled. Muscle biopsy was done which was found to be normal.
Discussion 
Out child had features suggestive of KSS Diagnostic a criterion, which were onset before 20 years of age, external Ophthalmoplegia, pigmentary retinopathy and CSF Protein more than 100mg/dl. 
Conclusion 
Kearns-Sayre syndrome should be considered in the differential diagnosis of children presenting with epilepsia Partialis continua.
publications.name: Kearns-Sayre Syndrome with Epilepsia Partialis Continua
Greig cephalopolysyndactyly with stroke in young
publications.description:
Introduction 
Greig cephalopolysyndactyly syndrome (GCPS) is a multiple congenital malformation characterized by limb and craniofacial anomalies, caused by heterozygous mutation or deletion of GLI3.
Case
Six year old boy presented with weakness of left upper and lower limb of 5 days duration. Child born to a consanguineously married couple, he was 3rd in birth order. Mother and other four siblings had Polysyndactyly. His initial milestones were delayed by 6 months.  On examination, head circumference of 55 cms, downward slanting of palpebral fissures, hypertelorism. Bilateral postaxial polydactyly with right side 3rd and 4th syndactyly and on left side 3rd, 4th, 5th and 6th syndactyly in the hands. In the feet, he had bilateral postaxial polydactyly with syndactyly of first and second, third and fourth, and fifth and sixth toes. His tone increased in left upper and lower limbs, power was 4/5 in left upper and lower limbs. Left knee, ankle and biceps were brisk and left plantar was extensor Investigations shows, right MCA infarct, panventriculomegaly and partial agenesis of corpus callosum on MRI. Work up for stroke doesn’t reveal any obvious cause. 
Discussion 
Our child had all the features suggestive of Greig cephalopolysyndactyly syndrome. No reports of association of this syndrome with stroke have been reported. 
Conclusion 
Greig cephalopolysyndactyly syndrome should be suspected any child presenting with large head, polydactyly with developmental delay. There might be on increased risk of stroke, as no other cause for stroke was identified in our child.

Introduction
               Glucose transporter-1 deficiency syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder, leading to a reduced glucose transport into the brain. We are reporting a child with infantile spasms, secondary to GLUT1 deficiency. 
Case Report
	A 12months old male child presented with infantile spasms since 5 months of age. He had refractory, mixed seizures, developmental delay followed by regression after onset of infantile spasms. He was born to a consanguineously married couple with history of similar complaints in two of the elder male sibling; both expired due to epilepsy around 5 years. Treated with multiple antiepileptic drugs without any response. He had microcephaly and choreo-athetosis. 
His ABG, lactate, ammonia, TMS, GCMS, MRI of brain, skin biopsy, and NCL enzyme assay were normal. EEG shows diffuse slowing. CSF showed low glucose (20 mg/dl) compared to blood glucose (102mg/dl). CSF lactate level was normal with no cells.  Hence suspected GLUT1 deficiency. Started with Ketogenic diet and later convulsions and Choreoathetosis stopped and development improved.  

Discussion
Glut 1 deficiency syndrome is defined by hypoglycorrhachia with normoglycemia, acquired microcephaly, episodic movements, and epilepsy refractory to antiepileptic drugs. All the clinical features and diagnostic criteria were present in our child, hence diagnosed as Glut 1 deficiency syndrome.  
Conclusion:
	When a child presents with refractory convulsions, simple CSF analysis to look for hypoglycorrhachia helps in diagnosis of GLUT1 deficiency. Ketogenic diet has to be started in these children for control of seizures and to prevent morbidity and mortality.
publications.name: Symptomatic West syndrome secondary to Glucose transporter -1(GLUT1) deficiency
Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid with neurocysticercosis
publications.description:
Introduction
Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid rare autosomal recessively inherited disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine 5 aminotransferase. Clinical manifestations include night blindness, myopia, loss of peripheral vision, and posterior sub-capsular cataract. 
Case
Twelve year old female child presented with convulsions since 5 years of age and night blindness since 1 year. Only child of non-consanguineously married couple with normal birth and developmental history. On examination, nystagmus, and bilateral retinitis pigmentosa with secondary optic atrophy were noted. Tone, power and reflexes were normal.  
Investigations show normal CBC, LFT, RFT, serum electrolytes, and EEG. MRI of brain shows features suggestive of calcified neurocyticercosis (NCC). ABG, lactate, and serum ammonia were within normal limits. TMS shows increased Ornithine-597.25 micro vol /L (Normal-0-220).
Discussion
Initially we thought of possibility of complex partial seizures with retinitis pigmentosa due to metabolic problems. However MRI of brain suggestive of NCC, an increase in ornithine in TMS more-than 5 folds with normal ammonia and retinal features were suggestive of gyrate atrophy of retina and choroid. We reconsidered out diagnosis as gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid with NCC. We were started with pyridoxine and treated seizures symptomatically, there was no further deterioration of vision during 18 months follow-up period. 
Conclusion
Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid should be considered in any child presenting with night blindness and normal cognition. In the presence of convulsions other causes should be considered.

publications.name: Hirshsprung’s disease with Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)
publications.description:
Introduction
Hirschsprung disease is a congenital form of aganglionic megacolon that results from cristopathy. Sensorineural deafness had been reported with this disease. 
Case Report
A 1 year 6 month old male child presented with complaints of inability to walk and hearing difficulty. He was able to sit and stand with support since 1 year 3 months, but was not able to walk with support. He was able to hold objects. He recognizes his parents but did not wave Bye-bye. No language milestones were attained, with parents complaining that he did not respond to his name or loud noises. In the past, he had been operated for Hirschsprung disease. 
On examination, the child was active, conscious and oriented. His head circumference was 44.5 cm, and was well nourished. CNS examination revealed hypotonia in all 4 limbs with diminished reflexes and a power of 3/5 in all 4 limbs. BERA shows bilateral profound hearing loss.
Discussion 
About 30% of the 120 million people worldwide who suffer from congenital hearing loss are syndromic. A significantly increased risk for dominant sensorineural deafness in patients who have Hirschsprung disease caused by endothelin receptor type B and SOX10 has been reported. Our child underwent surgery for Hirschsprung disease during newborn period later presented with not able to speak. Evaluation shows that he had severe sensory neural hearing loss. 
Conclusion 
Newborns with Hirschsprung disease should be screened for hearing impairment to detect early deafness and intervention.

publications.name: Homocystinuria with sagittal venous thrombosis: excellent recovery after administration of intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator
publications.description:
Introduction
Classic homocystinuria is caused by a deficiency of cystathionine beta synthase. 
Case
After uneventful pregnancy and normal birth, developmentally delayed seven years old boy presented with fever and altered sensorium of two days. On examination, superonasal lens subluxation with GCS- 8/15. CT and MRI were suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis.  His serum homocystine was >50 µmol/l. Homocysteinuria was considered in view of developmental delay, lens dislocation and increased homocystine. 
Thrombolysis of straight sinus was done and 2 mg of rTPA was given as bolus and infusion was started @ 2mg/hr. The radiological effect was reassessed with contrast venography at 12 hour intervals. rTPA infusion was discontinued after 36 hours with documentation of flow restoration. Heparin anticoagulation was maintained, and converted to oral warfarin therapy after 96 hours. Child developed hydrocephalus requiring VP shunt. He recovered completely without any sequelae. He also received pyridoxine, folic acid, and vitaminB12. During 18 months follow-up no recurrence of thrombosis. 
Discussion
Our child received tPA for 36 hrs with un-fractionated heparin for 96 hours followed by oral warfarin. The literature regarding the use of tPA in pediatric s with acute ischemic stroke is limited to observational data. There has been no report to the best of our knowledge who received tPA in CVT due to homocysteinuria with complete recovery. 
Conclusion	
Outcome in our child with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator in cerebral venous thrombosis with homocysteinuria are encouraging without complications.

publications.name: A RARE CASE REPORT OF INFANTILE OSTEOPETROSIS WITH HYDROCEPHALUS AND RICKETS
publications.description:
INTRODUCTION
Osteopetrosis is characterised by extensive sclerosis of the entire skeleton, increased tendency to fractures, cranial nerve palsies secondary to bony overgrowth of the foramina, hepatosplenomegaly, and anaemia and radiologically by a generalized increase in density of the bones and failure of tabulation. 
CASE 
A ten month old male infant born to a consanguineous parentage brought with complaints of progressive increase in head size noticed since 6 months of age with developmental delay, associated with downward deviation and roving movements of eye balls. Birth history was normal. Family history was unremarkable. On examination noted to have large head with wide and bulging anterior fontanelle, sutural diastasis and dilated prominent veins. Proptosis was present with sun set sign being positive, pallor present but no blue sclera. Systemic examination revealed massive splenohepatomegaly. Had visual impairment; however fundus was unremarkable except for pale disc. Hemogram showed anemia with thrombocytopenia. CT brain suggestive of aqueductal stenosis. Skeletal survey showed dense sclerotic bones, bone in bone appearance of long bones with rickets like picture.  All findings can be explained by severe infantile form of osteopetrosis.          
DISCUSSION
Osteopetrotic conditions vary greatly in their presentation and severity. Infantile variety is often associated with rickets-a paradoxical association. The presence of rickets worsens the symptoms of Osteopetrosis. We are describing a rare association of osteopetrosis, with hydrocephalus and rickets. 
Conclusion
Children presenting with hepatosplenomegaly and rickets with hydrocephalus, one should think possibility of hydrocephalus.

Introduction
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is characterized by elevated intracranial pressure with no clinical, laboratory, or radiographic evidence of infection, intracranial space occupying lesions, vascular abnormality, or hydrocephalus. We report a child who presented with similar findings following measles vaccination.

Case Report
Ten month old male baby presented with, deviation of eyes and irritability. He received measles vaccine, 4 days prior to the onset of the deviation. He had not received any other medicines, including vitamin A. On examination, baby was irritable, bilateral papilloedema, and paralytic convergent squint.
Investigations revealed a high CSF pressure with normal protein, sugar and no cells. CSF pressure was not measured because of non-availability of monitor. CBC, calcium, magnesium, electrolytes, LFT and RFT were normal. MRI of brain and orbit was normal. With above clinical and laboratory findings we diagnosed as IIH. Following LP, his irritability decreased and paralytic squint improved partially. He was started on acetazolamide. During follow up at 2 months the bilateral squint resolved and child was stable. 
Discussion
IIH can be caused in children due to various causes. In our child no cause was found, suggesting the IIH was related to measles vaccination.  As per our knowledge no cases of IIH were reported following measles vaccination, however described following measles infection.   
Conclusions
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension should be suspected in any child presenting with features paralytic squint with normal Neuroimaging. In addition to other causes described for IIH, measles vaccination also to be considered.
publications.name: Case Report – Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension following Measles vaccine?
Refractory Partial seizures due to epidermal nevus syndrome
publications.description:
Introduction 
Epidermal nevi are hamartomatous lesions characterized by hyperplasia of the epidermis and / or adnexal structures in a focal area of the skin. 
CASE
12 year old girl presented with left focal seizures since the age of one year of age. She has been treated with multiple antiepileptic drugs without any improvement in seizure frequency. Parents noticed skin lesion over the right face since one year of age. On examination, skin shows verrucous lesions over right side of the neck. MRI of brain shows atrophy with signal changes in right occipital region.EEG shows spike wave discharges arising from right Centro-occipital region. On skin biopsy, epidermis shows moderate acanthosis, papillomatosis and moderate orhtohyperkartosis. The dermis shows two large pilosebaceous units, with one showing dilated infundibulum with keratin. Mild perivascular lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates with few melanophages seen in the dermis. These features were consistent with verrucous epidermal nevus. Based on skin lesions, eye and MRI findings we diagnosed as epidermal nevus syndrome. 
Discussion 
Epidermal nevi are occasionally associated with other abnormalities of the skin and soft tissues, eyes, and nervous, cardiovascular, musculoskeletal, and urogenital systems. In these instances, the disorder is referred to as epidermal nevus syndrome. This child had skin lesions and CNS eye involvement, hence diagnosis of epidermal nevi is considered. 
Conclusion
In addition to sturge Weber syndrome, epidermal nevus syndrome should be considered in the differential diagnosis of children presenting with refractory focal seizures with skin lesions.

publications.name: Case Report –Spastic diplegia due to Arginase deficiency
publications.description:
Introduction
Hyperargininemia is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of enzyme Arginase.
Case Report
A 3 years old boy presented with difficulty in walking following fever of 5 days duration. He had started walking without support at 1 year of age and lost the ability to walk after the febrile episode. He was developmentally normal till 2 years of age. He speaks in bisyllables with normal social milestones.   He was the third born child of a 2nd degree consanguineous parentage. He was born by a home delivery with no significant antenatal or post natal complications. On examination, he appeared well nourished, with a normal head circumference. Tone was increased in both lower limbs with spasticity and exaggerated reflexes, with an extensor plantar response. Upper limbs and cranial nerves were normal. 
MRI of the brain was found to be normal. Serum ammonia levels were 66 mcg/dl and lactate values were 33 mg/dl which was relatively normal. Arterial blood gas analysis was normal. Tandem Mass Spectrometry showed a serum arginine level of 355.62 micromole/litre (3 - 130) with normal values of other amino acids. A diagnosis of Arginase deficiency was made and treated symptomatically. 
Discussion 
Clinical and lab reports in our child were suggestive of spastic diplegia due to Arginase deficiency. Unusual findings in our child were development of symptoms following acute febrile illness. 
Conclusion
Arginase deficiency should be suspected any child presenting with spastic diplegia with preserved cognition.

Introduction
Hemiconvulsion-Hemiplegia-Epilepsy syndrome (HHE) is an initial phase of unilateral seizures usually of long duration, with a second phase of hemiplegia, and then a third stage, of partial epileptic seizures.
Case 1
A ten month old baby girl was presented with fever, vomiting followed by left sided focal convulsions that lasted for two hours. On examination, GCS of 12/15 and left-sided weakness 1/5 .EEG showed asymmetry in voltage, left sided electrode voltage was 80% less than right. MRI revealed hyper intense signals seen in diffusion weighted images, which appeared dark on ADC images and isointense on T2 FLAIR images involving entire right hemisphere. Child’ GCS improved to 15/15 over next four days. Child had persistent hemiparesis with recurrence of left focal seizures during follow-up.  
Case 2
Three year old girl admitted with fever followed by left sided focal convulsions lasting for 45mins; the seizures recurred again within 24hours to last for two hours. He also had developmental delay. Examination revealed hypertonia of left upper and lower limb with power of 2/5 and exaggerated reflexes.EEG showed asymmetry in voltage. CT revealed hypodensity involving right fronto-temporo-parietal lobe and occipital lobe. During follow-up child had two episodes of left focal seizures which subsided with increasing carbamazepine. Repeat CT scan of brain showed atrophy of right cerebral hemisphere.
Conclusion 
In children presenting with focal febrile status epilepticus HHE syndrome should be considered as one of the possibilities in addition to complex febrile seizures and stroke in young.
publications.name: Hemiconvulsion-Hemiplegia-Epilepsy Syndrome; Report of two Indian Cases
Vanishing white matter disease after first booster dose of DPT vaccination
publications.description:
Introduction 	
Vanishing white matter disease is a recently described rare leukoencephalopathy that was initially called ‘childhood ataxia with central nervous system hypomyelinization (CACH). We report the presentation in a 1 and half year-old girl.
Case
One year six month old girl, born to consanguineously married couple with normal birth history. Developmental was normal till one year of age, after that not achieved further new milestones. She was admitted for fever, altered sensorium and convulsions after first booster dose of DPT vaccination. Weight (6kgs) and head circumference (39 cms) were below 3 SD. GCS was 9/15. Tone was decreased with brisk DTR. Choreoathetosis were noted. Moderate hepatosplenomegaly were noted. 
Her ABG, lactate, ammonia and TMS was normal. MRI showed diffuse periventricular, central white matter, dorsal brain stem, corpus callosum, globus pallidus cerebellar white matter T2W and FLAIR hyperintensities. MRS – mild elevation of choline, creatinine and lactate peak noted. Child was treated symptomatically. Child partially improved; was able to sit and could recognize parents. During follow-up of 10 months child did not lose further milestones. 

Discussion
 “Cree leucoencephalopathy” is a severe variant of VWM, with its onset between 3 and 9 months with hepatosplenomegaly. Rare findings in our case were Microcephaly, hepato-splenomegaly, and developmental arrest after first year of life and presented following DPT vaccination. 
Conclusion
Vanishing white matter disease should be suspected in case of acute loss of milestones following acute insult with previous developmental delay, Microcephaly and hepato-splenomegaly.

publications.name: MELAS presenting as cyclical vomiting
publications.description:
Eight years old boy presented with vomiting of 6 months duration, once in 7-10 days, lasting for 12-24 hours. He admitted first time with left focal seizures, weakness and drowsiness following fever of 2 days. CT brain- right temporo-parietal hypodensity with mild ipsilateral edema without enhancement. LP-CSF-normal. EEG- right fronto-temporal sharps with background asymmetry.  Treated with carbamazepine, mannitol, and acyclovir. Within 3 days, he readmitted with vomiting of 4 episodes with left focal seizures and weakness. Repeat LP-CSF protein- 55mg/dl. MRI brain-diffuse altered signal intensity of white matter of right tempro-occipital region, thalamus, left occipital region and hippocampus. He improved symptomatically with 10 days of IV acyclovir.
O/E, weight (13.5kgs), Ht (102 cms), and OFC (46 cms) were < 3rd percentile. Left sided power 4/5, DTR 2+. Lactate- 88, ammonia - 38. ABG – compensated metabolic acidosis, GI endoscopy- normal. Repeat CT –basal ganglia calcifications. Muscle biopsy-polygonal myofibers - variation in diameter, intensely stained with sub-sarcolemmal basophilic material, appear ragged blue on oxidative stain, ragged red on MGT and ragged on ATPase, type I fiber predominance, SDH-Cox-Cox deficient, suggestive of mitochondrial myopathy. ECHO-concentric LVH. 
MELAS is a clinical syndrome that characterized by Stroke like episodes (CT/ MRI-focal brain abnormalities); lactic acidosis, ragged red fibers, or both; and at least 2 of the following: dementia, focal or generalized seizures, recurrent headache, or vomiting. Our child had all features suggestive of MELAS. Hence any child presenting with unexplained seizures, focal deficits, encephalopathy and cyclical vomiting, one should suspect mitochondrial disorders.

publications.name: Rare cause of paraparesis-Spinal Arachnoid Cyst
publications.description:
Three months old, male baby presented with progressive weakness of both lower limbs since birth. Initially the child could lift up its limbs to some extent but now the child is unable to so, only move his limbs to sideways on the bed, to painful stimulus. There is no h/o trauma. There is no dribbling of urine or constipation. Child born at term by normal vaginal delivery by vertex presentation. 
On examination, his weight, length, and head circumference are within normal limits. Tone is decreased in bilateral lower limbs, power in bilateral lower limbs was 1/5 and in bilateral upper limbs was 3/5. Bilateral knee and ankle tendon reflexes were brisk. Bilateral plantar were extensor. No distension of bladder. Craniospinal axis was normal. 
MRI of spine shows- Large intradural arachnoid cyst extending from C5-D7 level which is compressing the cord between C5-D3-4 levels and shows minimal extension into neural foramina at multiple levels. Cord atrophy between C6-C7 and D2-3 levels.
Intradural extramedullary arachnoidal cysts are a rare cause of spinal cord or radicular compression and can be either idiopathic or the result of various events. Most of the reported cases represent solitary cysts in individuals who range in age from 10 to 69 years; the peak incidence is evident in the second decade of life. Our child presented immediately after birth is very unusual. We should think possibility of spinal cord malformations even when other features of spinal cord compression were absent in infancy.

publications.name: Two cases of congenital disorders of Glycosylation Type I from India.
publications.description:
Purpose- An informal survey of congenital disorders of glycosylation (CDG) affected families indicated that earlier nonspecific diagnoses frequently included a metabolic defect or cerebral palsy. Although CDG phenotypes are rare, their true frequency is unknown, and probably remain undiagnosed in many patients with mild or atypical manifestations. We report two children with different phenotypes.
Method and results
First case- Eight months old boy first sibling of non-consanguineously married couple with normal perinatal history, presented with history of global developmental delay since birth and seizures since 1 month. He does not follow light, and responds for only loud sound. On examination, head circumference (‹3 SD), inverted nipples, abnormal distribution of fat in gluteal regions, tapering fingers, increased tone and power 3/5 in all 4 limbs. Investigations shows, normal liver, renal, and thyroid functions, Serum ammonia, Tandem Mass spectroscopy, Gas chromatography and mass spectroscopy, abdominal ultrasonogrpahy, computed tomography of head, and arterial lactate.MRI of brain-diffuse cerebral atrophy, Visual Evoked Response - bilateral extinguished pattern, Electro encephalography-Diffuse slowing. Isoelectro focusing revealed-type I CDG.
Second case-Second sibling of third degree consanguineously married couple, presented with global developmental delay. Normal antenatal and perinatal history. Hearing was normal. On examination, normal head circumference, inverted nipples, abnormal gluteal fat distribution, decreased tone in all 4 limbs and truncal ataxia. Investigations- MRI- cerebellar atrophy. Normal lactate, Tandem Mass spectroscopy, Gas chromatography and mass spectroscopy. Isoelectro focusing revealed-type I CDG.
Conclusions- congenital disorders of glycosylation should be suspected any child presenting with developmental delay, cerebellar ataxia and abnormal fat distribution.

publications.name: Normative values for heart rate variability in children
publications.description:
Purpose -HRV is beat to beat variation in heart rate under resting conditions. It has good tool to quantify the tone of autonomic nervous system to the myocardium. It has been associated with high predictive value in many diseases. As there is no normative data in children, we did this study to document normative HRV data in children.
Methods- children of 2 to 15 years were included. Heart disease, diabetes and uremia were excluded. ECG was recorded in supine position for 5 min after 15 min of supine rest. Tests were done when child was comfortable. wave detection and RR intervals were done by software.
Results: Mean age was 9.10 ±3.3 (4-15) years, 18(45%) were male. Values were skewed, therefore we expressed in median and range. Low Frequency (LF)Power(ms2)-602(91-2880), High Frequency(HF)  Power(ms2)-1303(91-10707), LF/HF-0.56(0.13-9.65), Standard deviation of differences between adjacent RR intervals -48(13-1850), Co. of variance-7(4-1073), Variance- 2447(387-12924), Standard deviation of the R-R intervals-37(7-389), Root square of the mean of the sum of the squares of differences between adjacent RR intervals -47(13-931),Number R-R interval differences ≥ 50 ms - 60(1-306), Total power ms- 2192(529-15352), very low frequency nu-50(5-138),low frequency nu-36(11-90), high frequency nu-55(9-85),Total power nu-145(83-231), percentage of very low frequency-21(5-59), percentage of low frequency-26(8-57) and percentage of high frequency -46(6-75).
Discussion-our study results are comparable with Longin E et al (pediatr cardiol.2009.30:311-24).
Conclusion-HRV normative data is useful reference date to assess autonomic dysfunction in pediatric neurological disorders like, Guillain -Barre syndrome, refractory epilepsy, autonomic neuropathy and others.

publications.name: Complete Clinico-electrographic Response of Symptomatic west syndrome due to Biotidinase deficiency and hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy to Ketogenic diet in a child.
publications.description:
10 months old girl known case of biotidinase deficiency presented with seizures since the age of 45 days of life. Child had both multifocal seizures and flexor infantile spasms. Initially seizures partially responded for biotin. Later despite trial with multiple antiepileptic drugs including there was no response. 
At the age of 10 months child had daily flexor spasms of 3-4 cluster per day and 2-3 spasms per clusters. Child had global developmental with visual impairment. Before starting diet, child’s weight was 8.5 kgs, length-70 cms, head circumference 43 cms. Metabolic work up does not shows acidosis, (ABG-Ph-7.43, PcO2-34, hco3-19, BE—3) ketosis with normal liver function, renal function tests, lipid profile, normal urinary calcium creatinine ratio (0.001) Electroencephalogram showing modified hypsarrthmias. MRI sowing delayed myelination with minimal cerebellar atrophy. 
We started on 4:1 ratio ketogenic diet on out patient basis. Child tolerated diet during initiation without any complication and attained, urinary ketones 80-160 range. 
Spasms decreased to 1-2 clusters of 1-2 spasm per cluster per day over a period of one week. Child is spasm free for the last 6 months.  Weight increased by 900 grams over a period of 9 Months. Gaining milestones, attained head control, holds objects and recognizes mother voice. Also improvement in activity and alertness. There was no vomiting, nausea. Repeat arterial blood gases, liver function tests, renal function test, lipid profile, urinary calcium creatnine levels at 3 and 6 months of starting diet were within normal limits. Hypsarrthmias subsided in repeat EEG at the end of 6 moths.

publications.name: LATE ONSET TAYSACHS DISEASE (LOTS) PRESENTING AS PARAPARESIS
publications.description:
Four years old girl presented with progressive difficulty in walking since the age of 3 years. History of swaying of body on either side while standing and sitting. History of startle response was present. No history of cognitive regression, seizures, myoclonic jerks. She was a first child of non-consanguineously married couple with normal birth and developmental history. 
On examination, scanning speech, fundus shows bilateral cherry red spots, increased tone- bilateral lower limbs more than upper limbs, power of 3/5 in bilateral lower limbs and 4/5 in bilateral upper limbs. DTRs were brisk; signs of cerebellar dysfunctions were present. No hepatosplenomegaly. 
Investigations shows- Normal routine studies, MRI of brain shows cerebellar atrophy, low beta hexosaminidase levels. 
We are reporting this case as late onset taysachs is very rare and presenting as paraparesis is also unusual. Late onset taysachs can occur at any time during childhood, adolescence, or even adulthood, and their clinical expression is extraordinarily variable even within sibships, in contrast to early infantile variety. . We should suspect late onset taysachs disease, when any child presented with paraparesis with startle response and absent of hepato-splenomegaly.

publications.name: Situs Inversus with childhood stroke with Intracranial Vascular Malformation and Diabetes Mellitus with hypothyroidism
publications.description:
Purpose- We report a rare association of situs inversus child with type I diabetes mellitus presenting with childhood stroke with intracranial vascular malformation.
Method and results: Four year old male child was a case of Diabetes mellitus since the age of 2 years, presented with weakness of right sided upper and lower limb with right sided complex partial seizures of 4 months duration. On examination, right sided upper motor neuron type of weakness and heart sound better heard on right side of the chest with normal rest of the examination. Investigation shows dextrocardia on chest X ray, which was confirmed by echocardiography, abdominal ultrasonogrpahy shows liver on left side and spleen on right side. His diabetes mellitus controlled with 1.5 U/kg/day human insulin. His thyroid function shows increased thyroid stimulating hormone -8 IU, for that started on thyroxin. Screening for celiac disease was normal. Liver and renal function tests were normal. Electroencephalograph shows, epileptiform discharges from left frontocentral areas. MRI and MRA revealed mild diffuse let cerebral atrophy with absent of left sided A1 segment of anterior cerebral artery and left posterior communicating artery. Carotid Doppler was normal. Metabolic work for stroke, complete blood counts, coagulation profile, lupus anticoagulant, lipid profile, arterial lactate was normal. Cause of stroke doesn’t revealed any apparent cause, however complete left cerebral involvement can be explained on basis of left middle cerebral involvement with absent left anterior cerebral artery.
Conclusions- Intracranial vascular malformation should be suspected any child presenting with stroke with situs inversus.

publications.name: Clinical profile of 100 cases of Tuberous Sclerosis
publications.description:
Introduction: Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is a protean disease: the random distribution, number, size, and location of lesions cause varied clinical manifestations. (Smythe JF et al. Am J Cardiol 1990; 66:1247-49.) Few data are available for the rate of clinical signs that need imaging examinations in young children.
Methods: 100 cases of tuberous sclerosis studied -2007-2009.
Results –Out of 100 children, 69 were boys. Mean age group- 48.4 ±42.4 months. Seizures noted in 87, global developmental delay in 72, behavioral problems - 15, hearing problems in 11, speech difficulties in 45. Family history of TS present in 18, siblings in 6, parents in 10. Findings seen were hypo pigmented macules in 65, facial angiofibromas in 48, shagreen patches in 23, periungal fibromas in 2, forehead plaque in 5, confetti skin lesions in 4, and retinal hamartomas in 14. 
CT shows( done in 61 children) ,white matter heterotopia  in 18%, aqueductal stenosis in 1.6%, cortical tubers in 60.6%, Subependymal nodules in 80.3%, calcified nodules in 73.7%, astrocytoma in 1.6 %, hydrocephalus in 6.5%, cerebral atrophy in 8.1%, calcifications in 9.8%.
MRI shows (done in 32 children) white matter abnormalities-65.6 %, aqueductal stenosis- 3.1%, subependymal nodules- 87.5%, calcified nodules -9.3%, hydrocephalus - 6.2%, cortical atrophy - 3.1%,cortical tubers in frontal- 84.3%, parietal-75%, temporal -81.2% & occipital- 46.8%. 
Renal cysts in 9, benign renal tumor in 1, cardiac rhabdomyoma in 11.
Conclusions-Neurological manifestation- Seizures, developmental delay, and behavioral problems are commonest presentation of TS. Neuroimaging is helpful in diagnosis of TS.

Niemann-Pick group of diseases are rare lysosomal storage disorders. The clinical
phenotype is variable. We report a child who first time presented with tremors of tongue and
tremors of one side of the body. On examination child had hemiparesis and
hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow examination shows storage cells suggestive of
Niemann-Pick cells and enzyme assay confirmed the diagnosis.
publications.name: Niemann-Pick Disease Type A Presenting as Unilateral Tremors

publications.description:
Incontinentia Pigmenti is a rare neurocutaneous
disorder that may present with neurological symptoms in
early infancy in addition to characteristic skin rashes. We
report a two-mo-old girl presenting with a rash and encephalopathy.
Magnetic resonance imaging of brain showed
hemorrhagic infarcts. First we thought baby was suffering
from a skin infection with meningo-encephalitis and later
with development of characteristic skin lesions, neuroimaging
and skin biopsy changes we reconsidered our diagnosis
as Incontinentia pigmenti.
publications.name: Incontinentia Pigmenti Presenting as Encephalopathy

publications.description:
Six year old boy presented with skin lesions, initially
started on the left cheek at 2 years of age, then spread to
left lower eyelid and forehead. On examination, diffuse
sclerosis on the left cheek extending to left lower eyelid
was noted. Hypoplasia of left half of the face and
deviation of mouth and lips to left side were noted, with
loss of eyelashes in the left lower eyelid.
Differential diagnoses include hemifacial
microsomia (first and second branchial arch syndrome)
and its variants, such as Goldenhar syndrome, posttraumatic
atrophy and partial lipodystrophy (Barraquer-
Simon Syndrome). Hemifacial microsomia and
Goldenhar syndrome are congenital and non-progressive.
In post-traumatic atrophy, history of trauma will be
present. Lipodystrophy is usually bilateral and involves
primarily the adipose tissue. Parry-Romberg Syndrome
and localized scleroderma may represent differential
spectra of same disease. Parry-Romberg syndrome will
have hemifacial atrophy of the skin and tissue below the
Investigations show normal complete blood counts, renal
function tests, and liver function tests. Rheumatoid factor
and antinuclear antibody were negative. Skin biopsy
shows features suggestive of early morphea. CT scan of
brain was normal. CT scan of face shows hypoplastic left
maxillary sinus, left hemi-mandible, atrophy of the left
hemi-facial muscles and subcutaneous fat.
Parry-Romberg Syndrome is an uncommon
degenerative condition characterized by a slow and
progressive atrophy of facial tissues. A sharp demarcated
line between normal and abnormal skin called coup de
saber develops. The diagnosis is clinical and based on
characteristic cutaneous and soft tissue findings.
forehead, where as Localized scleroderma, generally
located in the fronto-parietal scalp and/or the paramedian
forehead, it may extend down the face as well.
It is an auto-limitable condition and there is no cure.
The treatment is usually based on reposition of adipose
tissue.
publications.name: Parry-Romberg Syndrome

publications.description: Sjögren-Larsson syndrome (SLS) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by triad of congenital ichthyosis, spastic paresis, and mental retardation. It is an inborn error of lipid metabolism caused by deficiency of the enzyme fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase. We report our observations of six children with SLS.
publications.name: Sjögren-Larsson syndrome: A study of clinical symptoms in six children

publications.description:
It was in 1825 that Caleb Parry described the term
progressive hemifacial atrophy, and the condition was
better studied by Moritz Romberg in 1846.[1] Parry–Romberg
syndrome (PRS) is characterized by progressive unilateral
atrophy of the facial tissues leading to severe disfigurement
with or without neurological complications. PRS may
be associated with or without cutaneous involvement
(linear scleroderma), en coup de sabre morphea, and
neurological involvement with signs like seizures,
trigeminal neuralgia, migraine headaches, ocular
abnormalities, malalignment of jaw causing dental
problems, and unilateral atrophy of tongue. In the internet
survey done by Stone, 11% of patients self‑reported
a diagnosis of epilepsy along with PRS. PRS may be rarely
associated with hemi‑masticatory spasm (HMS).
publications.name: Commentary -Parry Rombergs syndrome

Hereditary multiple exostoses (HME) is a benign condition characterized by the presence of multiple exostoses. Spinal cord compression resulting from vertebral osteochondroma is a rare complication of this entity and such a presentation in the first decade of life is rather rarer. 
A 9 year old girl presented with multiple bony swellings over the joints since last 5 years and progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months prior to presentation. On examination, multiple bony swellings noted over the medial side of left knee and lower thighs, lateral side of right elbow, anterior aspect of right arm and lateral side of right wrist. She had spasticity of all limbs and motor power was 3/5(MRC grade). She had exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. X ray of knee joints shows exostoses. MRI of the cervical spine demonstrated osteochondroma arising from the C2 lamina causing spinal canal narrowing with compression of spinal cord. Motor power improved following removal of the exostosis and spinal cord decompression.
The exostoses commonly involve metaphysis of long bones and less frequently vertebrae. It is an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with variable penetrance. No similar complaints in the patient’s family, she might be a sporadic case or the first case of her generation. Neurological dysfunction is most often caused by mechanical irritation; rarely due to nerve root and spinal cord compression. 
Reid et al, first to describe a case of myelopathy associated to HME. In the vertebral column, the cervical spine is commonly affected. In our patient too, C2 was involved.  The mean age of presentation is 20 years; our patient and the single case described by Labram et al  respectively are probably the only cases reported as presenting in the first decade of life. Compressive myelopathy due to osteochondroma is an uncommon condition, in patients with HME and can result in serious neurologic sequalae if not diagnosed and operated early.
publications.name: Multiple Exostoses Presenting With High Cervical Myelopathy in the First Decade of Life

ingestedContentSummary.description: Traumatic brain injury unmasking Vitamin B12 deficiency in an infant with long-term follow-up
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant concern in infants, requiring prompt evaluation and management to prevent potential complications. In the Indian scenario, 20–30% of head injuries are seen in the paediatric population between ages 1 and 16 years. [ 1 , 2 ] Vitamin B12 deficiency is very common in infancy and can lead to both haematological and neurological manifestations. Neurological manifestations include global developmental delay, neuroregression, irritability, lethargy, excessive crying, involuntary movements such as tremors and changes in behaviour such as agitation or withdrawal. [ 3 - 5 ] Haematological manifestations of Vitamin B12 deficiency include megaloblastic anaemia and pancytopenia. We report a case of a 6-month-old female infant who suffered an insignificant fall from a cot, resulting in intracranial haemorrhage due to previously unrecognised thrombocytopenia secondary to Vitamin B12 deficiency. A 6-month-old female infant was brought to the emergency room after an alleged history of falling from a cot with onset of vomiting and right focal seizures after three hours. On examination, her weight was 8 kg (0 to +1 Z score), and her head circumference was 42 cm (0 to −1 Z score). There was severe pallor and hypopigmented spar hair with knuckle hyperpigmentation. No external injuries were noted. Glasgow Coma Scale: 9/15, with equal and reactive pupils with a power of 3/5 (Medical Research Council [MRC] grade), was observed on the right side. Laboratory investigations revealed anaemia-haemoglobin of 6.1 g/dL with mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 106.7, thrombocytopenia (13 × 10 3 /uL) and low levels of serum Vitamin B12 121.2 pg/mL (normal 211–911 pg/mL) and increased levels of serum homocysteine of 89.83 μmoL/L (normal 3–50 μmoL/L). Peripheral smear examination indicated microcytic hypochromic cells, elongated cells, a few macro ovalocytes and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Serum iron was 59.04 ug/dL (35–145 ug/dL), Unsaturated iron binding capacity (UIBC) was 321.10 ug/dL (135–392 ug/ dL), total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) was 380.14 ug/ dL (250–400 ug/dL), transferrin was 310.2 mg/dL (200– 360 mg/dL), transferrin saturation was 15.53% (20–50%) and serum ferritin of 173.2 ng/Ml (20–110 ng/mL). Liver and renal function tests, serum electrolytes and metabolic workup done were normal. An initial computed tomography scan brain showed a haemorrhage in the left frontal region measuring 12 × 15 mm. Electroencephalogram showed focal epileptiform discharges arising from the left frontal region. A follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain after one month of trauma revealed volume loss and altered signal intensity in the left frontal lobe [ Figure 1a - c ], suggestive of gliosis due to injury. Given the clinical findings of TBI and concurrent Vitamin B12 deficiency, she received intravenous levetiracetam and 3% sodium chloride and supportive care. To address her anaemia, she received packed red blood cells and IV Vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin) at 1000 mcg/day for seven days followed by oral supplements continued for three months post-discharge. Due to persistent bicytopenia (severe anaemia and thrombocytopenia) during the prolonged hospital stay of 30 days, bone marrow aspiration was done, suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia. Laboratory values post-treatment were Vitamin B12 of 11850 pg/mL (normal 211–911 pg/mL) and normalised levels of homocysteine of 16.68 μmoL/L (normal 3–50 μmoL/L). Her last follow-up at three years of age was found to have mild residual right upper and lower limb weakness [ Figure 1d ]. This case report highlights the unmasking of Vitamin B12 deficiency in an infant following TBI. The fall from the cot resulted in TBI, leading to symptoms such as vomiting and seizures. Despite the seemingly insignificant nature of the fall, the presence of hemiparesis, brain haemorrhage observed on MRI, as well as the co-occurrence of anaemia and thrombocytopenia, raised concerns of underlying Vitamin B12 deficiency. Initially, anaemia was attributed to being secondary to brain haemorrhage by trauma, but the cause of thrombocytopenia could not be explained, which prompted further investigation into Vitamin B12 deficiency along with clinical manifestations. Other causes of anaemia and thrombocytopenia, such as leukaemia, were ruled out after a bone marrow examination. Identification of low Vitamin B12 levels in the patient led to the recognition of an underlying deficiency, which has implications for neurological functioning. Vitamin B12 deficiency is known to have neurological manifestations, including developmental delay/neuro regression, cognitive impairment in children, peripheral neuropathy and neuropsychiatric manifestations in the older age groups. [ 6 ] In addition to these effects, Vitamin B12 deficiency has also been associated with ischaemic stroke. [ 7 ] Studies have shown that Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in increased levels of homocysteine, an amino acid associated with an increased risk of vascular diseases, including stroke. [ 7 ] However, the exact mechanisms underlying the association between Vitamin B12 deficiency and worse outcomes in ischaemic stroke are still unknown. [ 7 ] While this case report focuses on detailed clinical examination and analysis of investigations influencing the outcome, prompt intervention and appropriate treatment played crucial roles in achieving favourable outcomes. The findings from this case report underscore the importance of considering concomitant nutritional deficiencies in infants with TBI, as they can contribute to the clinical presentation and influence management strategies. The child is currently three years old, with regular follow-up and achieving age-appropriate milestones, weight of 10.6 kg (−2 to −3 Z score), head circumference of 46 cm (at −3 Z score) and mild paucity of movements on the right side. The limitation of the report is we do not have clinical and radiological images during initial admission. TBI in infants can be complicated by underlying nutritional deficiencies, such as Vitamin B12 deficiency. This case report emphasises the significance of recognising and addressing concomitant deficiencies in infants with TBI, as they can impact clinical presentation and management strategies.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Traumatic brain injury unmasking Vitamin B12 deficiency in an infant with long-term follow-up

ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Rickettsial diseases are caused by a variety of obligate intracellular, Gram-negative bacteria from the genera Rickettsia, Orientia, Ehrlichia and Anaplasma . [ 1 ]. Rickettsial infections are underdiagnosed in India due to their non-specific clinical presentation. [ 2 ] The presence of an eschar, less commonly observed in the Indian population, contributes to the diagnostic process. Therefore, we are sharing this image to create more awareness of this treatable life-threatening condition. A 2-year-old female child presented with a fever lasting seven days and seizures on day 6 of fever. On examination, vital signs were stable, revealing three eschars: One over the mid back adjacent to the medial border of the left scapula [ Figure 1a ], over the back below the right scapular region [ Figure 1b ] and the third over the left mastoid region [ Figure 1c ]. On systemic examination, a Glasgow Coma Scale of 5/15, meningeal irritations, brisk deep tendon reflexes and hepatosplenomegaly were noted. Investigations revealed a total leukocyte count of 18700/mm 3 , haemoglobin of 10.7g/dL, platelet count of 44000/mm 3 , total protein of 4.2 g/dL, serum albumin of 1.8g/dL, aspartate aminotransferase of 279.3U/L, alanine aminotransferase of 123.1U/L, serum urea of 122.9 mg/dL and serum creatinine of 0.86 mg/dL. The Weil Felix test was positive for OXK (1:320). Serum and cerebrospinal fluid immunoglobulin M enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay were positive for Orientia tsutsugamushi . Work-up for other infections, such as dengue and malaria, was negative. The child was treated symptomatically and with oral doxycycline for seven days, leading to improvement in the child’s condition. Rickettsial eschars are necrotic lesions that occur at the site of tick or mite bites and represent locations of primary inoculation of spotted fever group Rickettsia and Orientia species. [ 3 ] A rickettsial eschar begins as a small, painless papule that appears within a few days after the bite of an infected vector. The papule grows, becomes vesicular or pustular and ulcerates, forming a brown-to-black crust surrounded by a red annular halo. The presence of an eschar can aid in the clinical and epidemiologic differentiation of less severe spotted fever rickettsioses from the more severe Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Rickettsial eschars serve as an important clinical specimen. [ 3 ]

ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Background: PRDM12 polyalanine tract expansions cause two different disorders; Midfacial Toddler Excoriation Syndrome (MiTES) - itch with normal pain sensation associated with homozygous 18 alanines (18A), and congenital insensitivity to pain (CIP) with normal itch with homozygous 19A. Knowledge of the phenotype, genotype, and disease mechanism of MiTES is incomplete. Why PRDM12 18A versus 19A can cause almost opposite phenotypes is unknown; no other poly-alanine or poly-glutamine tract expansion disease causes two such disparate phenotypes. Methods: We assessed the genotype and phenotype of 9 new, 9 atypical, and 6 previously reported patients diagnosed with MiTES. Using cell lines with homozygous PRDM12 of 12A (normal), 18A (MiTES) and 19A (CIP) we examined PRDM12 aggregation and subcellular localisation by image separation confocal microscopy and sub-cellular fractionation western blotting. Results: MiTES presents in the first year of life, and in all cases the condition regresses over the first decade leaving scarring. The MiTES phenotype is highly distinctive. Features overlapping with PRDM12-CIP are rarely found. The genotype-phenotype study of PRDM12 polyalanine tract shows that 7A -15A are normal; 16A -18A are associated with MiTES; 19A leads to CIP; and no clinically atypical MiTES cases had an expansion. PRDM12 aggregation and sub-cellular localisation differ significantly between 18A and normal 12A cell lines and between 18A and 19A cell lines. MiTES is a new protein aggregation disease. Conclusion: We provide diagnostic criteria for MiTES, and improved longitudinal data. MiTES and CIP are distinct phenotypes despite their genotypes varying by a single alanine in the PRDM12 polyalanine tract. We found clear distinctions between the cellular phenotypes of normal, MiTES and CIP cells.. We hypothesise that the developmental environment of the trigeminal ganglion is unique and critically sensitive to prenatal and postnatal levels of PRDM12. © The Author(s) 2024. Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of British Association of Dermatologists.

ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Background: Based on a limited number of reported families, biallelic CA8 variants have currently been associated with a recessive neurological disorder named, cerebellar ataxia, mental retardation, and dysequilibrium syndrome 3 (CAMRQ-3). Objectives: We aim to comprehensively investigate CA8-related disorders (CA8-RD) by reviewing existing literature and exploring neurological, neuroradiological, and molecular observations in a cohort of newly identified patients. Methods: We analyzed the phenotype of 27 affected individuals from 14 families with biallelic CA8 variants (including data from 15 newly identified patients from eight families), ages 4 to 35 years. Clinical, genetic, and radiological assessments were performed, and zebrafish models with ca8 knockout were used for functional analysis. Results: Patients exhibited varying degrees of neurodevelopmental disorders (NDD), along with predominantly progressive cerebellar ataxia and pyramidal signs and variable bradykinesia, dystonia, and sensory impairment. Quadrupedal gait was present in only 10 of 27 patients. Progressive selective cerebellar atrophy, predominantly affecting the superior vermis, was a key diagnostic finding in all patients. Seven novel homozygous CA8 variants were identified. Zebrafish models demonstrated impaired early neurodevelopment and motor behavior on ca8 knockout. Conclusion: Our comprehensive analysis of phenotypic features indicates that CA8-RD exhibits a wide range of clinical manifestations, setting it apart from other subtypes within the category of CAMRQ. CA8-RD is characterized by cerebellar atrophy and should be recognized as part of the autosomal-recessive cerebellar ataxias associated with NDD. Notably, the presence of progressive superior vermis atrophy serves as a valuable diagnostic indicator. © 2024 The Authors. Movement Disorders published by Wiley Periodicals LLC on behalf of International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society. Keywords: CA8; ataxia; cerebellar atrophy; vermis atrophy. © 2024 The Authors. Movement Disorders published by Wiley Periodicals LLC on behalf of International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society.

ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Vol.:(0123456789) Indian Journal of Pediatrics https://doi.org/10.1007/s12098-024-05107-z CORRESPONDENCE Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis due to ALS2 Pathogenic Variant Masquerading as Cerebral Palsy: Authors’ Reply Vykuntaraju K. Gowda1  · Sharath Babu1 · Uddhava Kinhal2 · Varunvenkat M. Srinivasan3 Received: 9 March 2024 / Accepted: 14 March 2024 © The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Dr. K C Chaudhuri Foundation 2024 To the Editor: We appreciate Finsterer J. for critical review and comments on our article published in IJP [1]. Regarding queries raised by the author [2], we would like to highlight our case. The phenotypes associated with ALS2 variants can be following: Juvenile onset Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) type 2 (OMIM#205100), Juvenile primary lateral sclerosis (OMIM#606353) and Infantile onset ascending spastic paraparesis (OMIM#607225) [3]. The clinical fea- tures of the above three phenotypes are overlapping as all of them come under the group of Motor Neuron disorders. Even though the gene causes 3 phenotypes, our case had ALS phenotype as there were signs of denervation on elec- tromyography, hence reporting as ALS. We could not test the parents for the variant due to cost constraints; however, both the parents were asymptomatic clinically. We do not have objective evidence of Apgar score, but child was apparently well with smooth fetal to neonatal transition phase. Child did not require neonatal intensive care unit support immediately after delivery. As per his- tory, encephalopathy was present in the index case in the form of lethargy and poor feeding. There were no objective grading or scaling documents available to diagnose or grade encephalopathy. Encephalopathy did not last more than 5–6 d based on history given by parents. Probable cause was kept as sepsis or hypoglycemia based on historical points given by caretakers. We have undertaken extensive investigations which includes metabolic testing by tandem mass spectrom- etry, urinary organic acids, serum lactate and ammonia, arte- rial blood gases to exclude other causes, which were all nor- mal. Hence based on clinical phenotype and investigations, we diagnosed the case as ALS. Declarations Conflict of Interest None. References 1. Gowda VK, Babu S, Kinhal U, Srinivasan VM. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis due to ALS2 pathogenic variant masquerading as cerebral palsy. Indian J Pediatr. 2024. https:// doi. org/ 10. 1007/ s12098- 024- 05081-6. 2. Finsterer J.
